title: Tepoto (North)
text:
Tepoto, also known as Te Poto, Toho, or Pukapoto, is a <a href="coral">coral</a> <a href="island">island</a>. It is the northwesternmost of the <a href="Disappointment%20Islands">Disappointment Islands</a>, in the <a href="Tuamotus">Tuamotu Archipelago</a>. Despite being often referred to as "atoll", Tepoto is not a typical Tuamotu atoll, but a single separate island without a lagoon. It is located at the limit of the Tuamotu archipelago; the closest land is <a href="Napuka">Napuka</a>, which lies to the southeast.
Tepoto is long and wide; it has an area of . This island is sometimes called Tepoto Nord in <a href="French%20language">French</a>, to avoid confusion with <a href="Tepoto%20%28South%29">Tepoto</a> Atoll (Tepoto Sud) to the southwest, in the <a href="Raeffsky%20Islands">Raeffsky Islands</a> of central Tuamotu. An obsolete name is Otuho.
According to the 2012 <a href="census">census</a>, its population was 61 inhabitants. The primary village is <a href="Tehekega">Tehekega</a>. There is a wide road running around the whole island.
In 2018 there were about 40 residents, 13 of which were children under the age of 12.
History.
The first recorded European to arrive at Tepoto Nord was explorer <a href="John%20Byron">John Byron</a> in 1765. 
He named Napuka and Tepoto "Disappointment Islands" because of the lack of a safe <a href="anchorage%20%28maritime%29">anchorage</a> and the hostility of the natives.
Administration.
Tepoto Nord belongs to the <a href="Commune%20in%20France">commune</a> of Napuka. The commune of Napuka consists of the atolls of Napuka and Tepoto Nord.
